title: Writing: Paragraph Structure

vocab.definition: A group of sentences about one main idea.
The sentence that states the main idea of the paragraph.
To start the first line of a paragraph further in from the margin.

teachingNotes: Use the 'hamburger' or 'sandwich' analogy: the top bun is the topic sentence, the fillings are the supporting details, and the bottom bun is the concluding sentence. This visual helps students remember all the necessary parts.

sample.question: What are the three main parts of a paragraph?
expectedAny: Topic sentence, supporting details, concluding sentence

sample.question: What is the first sentence of a paragraph usually called?
What does a topic sentence do?
expectedAny: It tells the main idea of the paragraph.

sample.question: How many main ideas should a single paragraph have?
What is the job of the supporting sentences in a paragraph?
expectedAny: To give details and explain the main idea.

sample.question: What is the purpose of a concluding sentence?
expectedAny: To wrap up the paragraph or restate the main idea.

sample.question: Why do we indent the first line of a paragraph?
expectedAny: To show that a new paragraph is starting.

truefalse.question: A paragraph is a group of sentences that are all about one main topic.
Every paragraph should have a topic sentence.
A single paragraph can be about many different topics at once.
The topic sentence is usually the first sentence in a paragraph.
Supporting sentences give more details about the topic sentence.
A concluding sentence is not a necessary part of a paragraph.
Paragraphs should always be indented to show where they begin.

multiplechoice.question: A well-written paragraph should have ___ main idea(s).
The first line of a new paragraph is usually ___.
A good paragraph usually contains at least ___ sentences.
Words like 'first,' 'next,' and 'finally' are called transition words and help to ___.

fillintheblank.question: The ___ sentence tells the reader what the paragraph will be about.
You should ___ the first line of every new paragraph.
___ sentences provide details, facts, and examples.
A ___ sentence brings the paragraph to a close.
All the sentences in a paragraph should relate to one main ___.
Using paragraphs helps to organize our ___.
___ words like 'also' or 'for example' help connect ideas within a paragraph.

shortanswer.question: What are the qualities of a good topic sentence?
expectedAny: It is clear, states the main idea, and is interesting enough to make someone want to read more.

shortanswer.question: How do you organize the sentences in a paragraph?
expectedAny: Start with the topic sentence, follow with supporting details, and end with a concluding sentence.

shortanswer.question: Why is it important to use paragraphs in your writing?
expectedAny: They organize ideas into logical sections and make the text easier for others to read and understand.

shortanswer.question: About how many sentences should be in a paragraph?
expectedAny: It can vary, but a good paragraph usually has between 3 and 8 sentences.

shortanswer.question: Give two examples of transition words you could use in a paragraph.
expectedAny: First, next, then, finally, also, however

shortanswer.question: How do you know when it's time to start a new paragraph?
expectedAny: When you are ready to write about a new main idea or topic.

shortanswer.question: Write a strong topic sentence about your favorite animal.
expectedAny: Tigers are fascinating animals because of their strength, speed, and beautiful stripes.
